text: Situation A. Arch Middle School Stairs

A set of stairs is being built for the front of the new Arch Middle School. The ratio of rise to run is 7 to 11.
  • Is this ratio within the carpenters’ guidelines?

content.text:
2(rise) + run = 2(7) + 11 = 14 + 11 = 25, which is between 24 and 26 inches. 
Rise + run = 7 + 11 = 18, which is between 17 and 19 inches.
Yes, these stairs meet the carpenters’ guidelines. Note that a scaled-up equivalent ratio of 14 to 22 would not meet the guidelines.

text: • Make a sketch of a set of stairs that meet this ratio. Label the lengths of the rise and run of a step. Does everyone in your class have the same sketch? Explain.

content.text:
Student answers will vary.
Example: a set of stairs with a height of 3.5 inches and a depth of 5.5 inches.

tiles.title: Stairs with rise of 3.5 inches and run of 5.5 inches

text: Not everyone in the class will have the same sketch because even the same ratio can be represented by different numbers. And, some students will have measured different stairs.
• Write an equation that represents the relationship between rise and run.

content.text:
Student answers will vary based on their stairs.
Example answer using the stairs at Arch Middle School, rise = (7/11)run.

text: • How is the ratio of rise to run represented in the graph? Equation?

content.text: The ratio of rise to run is represented in the graph by the steepness of the line and in the equation by the coefficient of x.

text: • Does your graph represent a proportional relationship? Explain why.

content.text: The graph does represent a proportional relationship because it passes through the origin.

text: Situation B. Anna’s Claim
Anna's Claim

The ratio of rise to run is another way to express the pattern of change between the two variables in a linear situation.
  • Is she correct? Explain why.

content.text: Yes, she is correct. The ratio of rise to run describes how much one variable changes if you change the other variable by a specific amount. If the variables are always related in this way, then they have a constant rate of change, which gives a linear relationship.

text: • Does the ratio change if we take two steps at a time? Explain why.

content.text: No, because we’re rising twice as high and running twice as far.  So, the ratio will stay the same.

text: Situation C More Lines
The points (3, 5) and (–2, 10) lie on a line.
• What is the ratio of rise to run of the line?
The ratio of rise to run of the line is (10 – 5)/( –2 – 3)= (10 –5)/(–2 –3) = 5/(–5) = –1
• Find two more points that lie on this line. Explain your method.
Student answers will vary.
For example, (–1,9) is on the line because you can increase the x-coordinate of (–2,10) by 1 and decrease the y-coordinate of (–2,10) by 1.
• Write an equation for this line. How is the ratio of rise to run reflected in the equation?
Equation: y = –1x + 8

• Does this line represent a proportional relationship? Explain.
This line does not represent a proportional situation because it does not pass through the origin. Also, the values from the table cannot be used to create proportions.
• What is the ratio of rise to run of a horizontal line? A vertical line? Explain your reasoning.

The rate of change of a horizontal line is 0 because there is no “rise” no matter how far you “run.” The rate of change of a vertical line is undefined because there is no “run” no matter how far you “rise.”
